item.title: Threat and Race
item.description:
Threat and Race

There has always been a debate between the links of fatal police shootings and victims. There has even been insinuations that race has an effect on the threatening nature of these individuals. This topic often sparks outrage within the black and POC communities and within law enforcement.

I’m going to try to explore this sensitive topic and try to make some inferential findings.

The Data

The dataset can be found here.

We have three variables to look at: “attack”, “other”, and “undetermined”. Attack constitutes as the individual was reported to have posed immediate threat to the officer. “Other” is every other level of threat and “undetermined” is for any circumstance that through the vetting process, threat level could not be determined. Keep in mind how the level of threat is determined, as explained in the home page.

Let’s look at the visualization of the raw numbers/counts. Figure 1 below shows the level of reported threat by race.

Figure 1. Amount of Fatal Police Shootings by Race since 2015

All three graphs look identical. The only visual difference is the volume of the counts. I think in this case, looking at the proportions will be more inferenital.

When Victims are Threatening

I wanted to explore some general statistics of when a victim pose an immediate threat to a police officer’s life. Figure 2 depics a boxplot with the proportions of those who pose immediate threat to an officers life by race.

Figure 2. Box plot and distribution of the proportions of victims who are recorded to have posed a threat to an officer’s life by race from 2015 to current.

From 2015 to current, it is depicted trough Figure 2 that the largest proportion of those who are recorded to be threatening have tended to be White, then Black, Hispanic, Not Recorded, Asian, Native and Other, respectively.

Display 1 is the output of a regression model in where we predict the proportion of the attack threat level via race. Our R-squared adjusted=.9131 and the p-value=2.2e-16 meaning that the regression is an appropriate model to predict the proportion of individuals that pose a threat on an officer’s life by race.

The regression model: \[ predicted(proportion) = 0.014 + 0.227(Black) + 0.1323(Hispanic) -0.002(Native) + 0.106(Not Recorded) - 0.006(Other) + 0.443(White) \] 91.31% of the variation in proportion of those who are threatening is explained through the differences in race, but are these differences significant?

A One-way ANOVA (Display 2) was done to test if there is at least one mean proportion from a single race is significantly different to another. The p-value<2e-16. We have enough statistical evidence to conclude at least one mean proportion of one race was significantly different than another race. A Tukey’s comparison post hoc to see what these differences are.

Figure 3 and Display 3 shows the output for the Tukey’s comparison of means. The output here can be hard to interpret, so a connecting letters plot was made in Figure 4. Significant differences are denoted as having different letters above each boxplot. Asian, Native and Other all have the same letter, their mean proportions are not significantly different from one another, though they are significantly different than the rest of the races. Hispanic and the proportions of those who race is recorded as Not Recorded have no significant differences to each other. Black is significantly different than all other races. White is also significanly different than all other races.
